originContent: Since version 2.0, this tool has been rewritten in Rust. The previous Python version can be found in the [v1 branch](https://github.com/desbma/hddfancontrol/tree/v1). See [Migrating from v1.x](#migrating-from-v1x) for migration.
translatedContent: Since version 2.0, this tool has been rewritten in Rust. The previous Python version can be found in the [v1 branch](https://github.com/desbma/hddfancontrol/tree/v1). See [Migrating from v1.x](#migrating-from-v1x) for migration.

originContent: HDD Fan control is a command line tool to dynamically control fan speed according to hard drive temperature on Linux.
translatedContent: HDD Fan control is a command line tool to dynamically control fan speed according to hard drive temperature on Linux.

originContent: - it allows maintaining your hard drives in the ideal temperature range to have maximum longevity and avoid overheating
translatedContent: - it allows maintaining your hard drives in the ideal temperature range to have maximum longevity and avoid overheating

originContent: Because fans will slow down or stop when not needed:
translatedContent: Because fans will slow down or stop when not needed:

originContent: - it minimizes noise generated by the fans
translatedContent: - it minimizes noise generated by the fans

originContent: - it minimizes power consumption at the same time
translatedContent: - it minimizes power consumption at the same time

originContent: HDD Fan control is useful when you have one or several hard drives with one or several fans close to them, and do not want to let the motherboard control the fan speed, because it does so either statically, or using a temperature sensor unrelated to the real drive temperature (either on the CPU or on some other place on the motherboard).
translatedContent: HDD Fan control is useful when you have one or several hard drives with one or several fans close to them, and do not want to let the motherboard control the fan speed, because it does so either statically, or using a temperature sensor unrelated to the real drive temperature (either on the CPU or on some other place on the motherboard).

originContent: The ideal use case is for a NAS with several hard drives, a low power CPU (ie. ARM or Intel Atom) with passive cooling (no fans), and a chassis with fans close to the hard drive. It that case the CPU will generate less heat than the hard drives and it makes sense to control fan speed according to the main heat source.
translatedContent: The ideal use case is for a NAS with several hard drives, a low power CPU (ie. ARM or Intel Atom) with passive cooling (no fans), and a chassis with fans close to the hard drive. It that case the CPU will generate less heat than the hard drives and it makes sense to control fan speed according to the main heat source.

originContent: - Can control several fans and/or several drives with a single invocation
translatedContent: - Can control several fans and/or several drives with a single invocation

originContent: - Supports 6 different ways of querying temperature:
translatedContent: - Supports 6 different ways of querying temperature:

originContent: - Can adapt to different fan characteristics
translatedContent: - Can adapt to different fan characteristics

originContent: - Can be customized to your needs:
translatedContent: - Can be customized to your needs:

originContent: - to stop fans or run them at full speed at customizable temperatures
translatedContent: - to stop fans or run them at full speed at customizable temperatures

originContent: - to never set the fans below a certain speed (useful if the fans controlled by HDD Fan control are the only ones available in the chassis)
translatedContent: - to never set the fans below a certain speed (useful if the fans controlled by HDD Fan control are the only ones available in the chassis)

originContent: - Can also optionally monitor CPU temperature, and control fan speed accordingly
translatedContent: - Can also optionally monitor CPU temperature, and control fan speed accordingly

originContent: - A least one SATA/SAS\* hard drive, that supports:
translatedContent: - A least one SATA/SAS\* hard drive, that supports:

originContent: - exposes to the OS a PWM to control fan speed
translatedContent: - exposes to the OS a PWM to control fan speed

originContent: - exposes to the OS a sensor to query fan speed
translatedContent: - exposes to the OS a sensor to query fan speed

originContent: Most motherboards and SATA drives fit these requirements.
translatedContent: Most motherboards and SATA drives fit these requirements.

originContent: \* There has been several reports of `hddfancontrol` working well with SAS drives, however this has been less tested than SATA.
translatedContent: \* There has been several reports of `hddfancontrol` working well with SAS drives, however this has been less tested than SATA.
Some Linux distributions have a hddfancontrol package available in their repository:

originContent: Some Linux distributions have a hddfancontrol package available in their repository:

translatedContent: See [GitHub releases](https://github.com/desbma/hddfancontrol/releases) for other packages/binaries built for each tagged version.

originContent: See [GitHub releases](https://github.com/desbma/hddfancontrol/releases) for other packages/binaries built for each tagged version.

translatedContent: You need a Rust build environment for example from [rustup](https://rustup.rs/).

originContent: You need a Rust build environment for example from [rustup](https://rustup.rs/).

translatedContent: Also install [hdparm](http://sourceforge.net/projects/hdparm/), [smartctl](https://www.smartmontools.org/), [sdparm](https://sg.danny.cz/sg/sdparm.html) (for SAS drive support), and optionally [hddtemp](http://www.guzu.net/linux/hddtemp.php).

originContent: Also install [hdparm](http://sourceforge.net/projects/hdparm/), [smartctl](https://www.smartmontools.org/), [sdparm](https://sg.danny.cz/sg/sdparm.html) (for SAS drive support), and optionally [hddtemp](http://www.guzu.net/linux/hddtemp.php).
translatedContent: On recent Ubuntu and other Debian derivatives: `sudo apt install hdparm sdparm smartmontools`.

originContent: On recent Ubuntu and other Debian derivatives: `sudo apt install hdparm sdparm smartmontools`.

translatedContent: See [systemd service](#systemd-service) to easily manage the daemon.

originContent: See [systemd service](#systemd-service) to easily manage the daemon.

translatedContent: The default parameters will run fans at 100% speed at temperatures > 50째C, and run them a 20% speed if < 30째C, which corresponds to the usual recommended drive operating temperature. If you are sure that there are no other components in your system that generate significant heat, if you have other fans to cool down your system, or if you have a case optimized for passive cooling, you can set minimum speed to 0%, which will stop the fans if temperature is below the minimum threshold.

originContent: The default parameters will run fans at 100% speed at temperatures > 50째C, and run them a 20% speed if < 30째C, which corresponds to the usual recommended drive operating temperature. If you are sure that there are no other components in your system that generate significant heat, if you have other fans to cool down your system, or if you have a case optimized for passive cooling, you can set minimum speed to 0%, which will stop the fans if temperature is below the minimum threshold.

translatedContent: **Be aware that a misconfiguration of this tool can lead to a failure to cool down your system properly which can damage components or reduce their lifetime.**

originContent: **Be aware that a misconfiguration of this tool can lead to a failure to cool down your system properly which can damage components or reduce their lifetime.**

translatedContent: Before using HDD Fan control unmonitored for long period of time, I recommend keeping a minimum fan speed for security, and checking that the temperature of your system stays in reasonable range as expected.

originContent: Before using HDD Fan control unmonitored for long period of time, I recommend keeping a minimum fan speed for security, and checking that the temperature of your system stays in reasonable range as expected.

translatedContent: To get the start/stop values for the `--pwm` parameter, you can either:

originContent: To get the start/stop values for the `--pwm` parameter, you can either:

translatedContent: - Use the `pwm-test` command (`hddfancontrol pwm-test ...`), which will run some tests and detect the values at which the fans start and stop. However you need to have previously identified the PWM file (the `--pwm` parameter)

originContent: - Use the `pwm-test` command (`hddfancontrol pwm-test ...`), which will run some tests and detect the values at which the fans start and stop. However you need to have previously identified the PWM file (the `--pwm` parameter)

translatedContent: See [detailed changelog](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/desbma/hddfancontrol/master/./CHANGELOG.md) for all changes since initial version 2.

originContent: See [detailed changelog](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/desbma/hddfancontrol/master/./CHANGELOG.md) for all changes since initial version 2.

translatedContent: With version 2, `hddfancontrol` has been completely rewritten in the Rust language. The main changes coming from version 1 are:

originContent: With version 2, `hddfancontrol` has been completely rewritten in the Rust language. The main changes coming from version 1 are:

translatedContent: - `hddfancontrol` is a compiled binary, and does not require a Python interpreter anymore.

originContent: - `hddfancontrol` is a compiled binary, and does not require a Python interpreter anymore.
translatedContent: - Command line arguments are slightly changed, and will required to be manually adjusted, either in your `hddfancontrol` invocations, or in the `/etc/conf.d/hddfancontrol` file if you use it through the systemd service. See `hddfancontrol daemon -h` for a reference.

originContent: - Command line arguments are slightly changed, and will required to be manually adjusted, either in your `hddfancontrol` invocations, or in the `/etc/conf.d/hddfancontrol` file if you use it through the systemd service. See `hddfancontrol daemon -h` for a reference.
translatedContent: - The auto drive spin down feature has been removed. If you need it, I recommend using [hd-idle](https://github.com/adelolmo/hd-idle) (beware there are several similarly named projects), which works well alongside `hddfancontrol`.

originContent: - The auto drive spin down feature has been removed. If you need it, I recommend using [hd-idle](https://github.com/adelolmo/hd-idle) (beware there are several similarly named projects), which works well alongside `hddfancontrol`.

translatedContent: Run `hddfancontrol -h` to get full command line reference.

originContent: Run `hddfancontrol -h` to get full command line reference.

translatedContent: As an example, the command line below will instruct HDD Fan control to:

originContent: As an example, the command line below will instruct HDD Fan control to:

translatedContent: - control fan speed using PWM 2 and 3 in `/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon1/device/`

originContent: - control fan speed using PWM 2 and 3 in `/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon1/device/`
translatedContent: - start both fans using PWM value 200

originContent: - start both fans using PWM value 200
translatedContent: - consider the fans will stop with PWM value 75

originContent: - consider the fans will stop with PWM value 75
- never run the fans below 10% of their maximum speed
translatedContent: - never run the fans below 10% of their maximum speed

originContent: - check temperature at least every minute
translatedContent: - check temperature at least every minute

originContent: A systemd service file is provided to control the daemon easily.
translatedContent: A systemd service file is provided to control the daemon easily.

originContent: If you installed hddfancontrol from a distribution package, you likely already have it installed, otherwise you can install it from the sources of this repository with:
translatedContent: If you installed hddfancontrol from a distribution package, you likely already have it installed, otherwise you can install it from the sources of this repository with:

originContent: Then you need to edit the `HDDFANCONTROL_DAEMON_ARGS` variable in `/etc/conf.d/hddfancontrol` to set the parameters (drives, temperature range...).
translatedContent: Then you need to edit the `HDDFANCONTROL_DAEMON_ARGS` variable in `/etc/conf.d/hddfancontrol` to set the parameters (drives, temperature range...).

originContent: You can then start the daemon with `sudo systemctl start hddfancontrol`, see its status with `sudo systemctl status hddfancontrol` and enable automatic startup at boot time with `sudo systemctl enable hddfancontrol`.
translatedContent: You can then start the daemon with `sudo systemctl start hddfancontrol`, see its status with `sudo systemctl status hddfancontrol` and enable automatic startup at boot time with `sudo systemctl enable hddfancontrol`.
